25721640.review:
Disclosure: I was given a free key by the developer.

-=The Good=-

Stylish vector visuals
Good music
Interesting combination of gameplay styles
Solid controls
Centipede-inspired bonus levels
Multiple game modes


-=The Bad=-

Unkillable enemies
Occasional cheap deaths
Low powerup drop rate
Slow "Hyper" filling


-=The Details=-

The game itself is an interesting combo-pack of ideas, some of which are borrowed from Flump Studios' previous game, Horizon Shift (HS). From the vector graphic-designed enemies that look like they could have been in HS, to the animation playing faintly behind all of the action, it screams HS in look and presentation. However, the similarities end there for the most part. This is basically a twin-stick shooter, as you control the gun with the right stick, and movement with the left. But rather than just move around freely over the entire play area ala Smash TV or Robotron 2084, you're main area is along the bottom of the screen not unlike Space Invaders or Galaga.  From there, you'll go after the red and green enemies for score and bonuses while avoiding their bullets by either moving/jumping out of the way, or bouncing off of blue objects to make yourself invincible.

Yes, you heard right, you'll be jumping and bouncing in this game. By jumping onto a low-moving blue object (or using a wall jump like in NES' Ninja Gaiden to reach a higher blue object), you become invincible to bullets and enemies. Not only that, the destroyed blue objects leave gems behind for you to collect either by hitting the floor and catching as many as you can as they fall, or by hitting the ceiling and getting them all. Another perk of the blue enemies is that bouncing off of them allows you to absorb bullets to fill up a Hyper meter that can be used to unleash a large blast that destroys most enemies (or get a big bonus... if you know how). As a bonus, if you can destroy groups of green ships, you gain a star. And if you collect five stars, you get taken to a bonus level at the end of the current stage to fight in what is clearly an homage to Centipede.

The action starts slow, but gradually builds into a frenzied skirmish of shooting, avoiding and collecting. The bosses in the game are the same way; starting off simple, but getting more demanding with each new one in terms of how you damage it and its bullet patterns. Thankfully, the controls are responsive and the hit detection seems to be on point as well. And as you frantically do all of this, you'll have some enjoyable music to listen to thanks to the OST that features catchy, synthy beats.

Sounds good, right? And for the most part, it is. But there are some issues with the game. First and foremost, are the unkillable enemies. This is a personal taste thing, but I HATE enemies you can't kill, especially when there are a lot of them. I've always felt they were a somewhat cheap way to add difficulty to a stage or section (I'm all for making a given enemy-type tough, but not indestructible). And sadly, this game features these undying things in the form of laser cannons that fire when you touch the ground, laser cannons that fire at timed intervals, and buzzsaws that go around the edges of the entire play area. All you can do is avoid them, which gets tedious after awhile and frustrating toward the end of the game... especially when they cause an unfair death.

Yes, this game has them too. There have been times where I beat the level, but triggered the floor laser cannons just as the level was ending. The result was the cannon's firing while the rest of the stage was blowing up. More than once, I found myself unavoidably falling into the laser blast and losing a life as the stage ended. I also encountered similarly unfair deaths after dropping from the ceiling. See, when you touch the ceiling and get all of the gems on-screen, you drop to the floor again. The problem is, you can't land on any blue objects as you fall. You just pass through them due to the invincibility you're given at that moment. When you hit the floor again, you become vulnerable again right away and that's where I got killed by bullet groups that I couldn't avoid thanks to how hectic things start getting around the mid-way point of the game.

A final pair of complaints come from the way powerups are handed out and how long it takes to fill the Hyper meter. It seems as if the powerups drop rather infrequently, and I've yet to figure out if it's because I'm not doing something right/often enough to trigger them, or if the game's just stingy with them. Either way, you really start feeling under-powered when you play through 15 stages and only get one powerup (if you're lucky). Lastly, the Hyper meter always seems to take forever to fill. And as if that weren't enough, I've watched it get emptied out without using it or dying. I'm still trying to figure out if that last part's intentional, or a bug in the game.

So in the end, what can be said about Hyper Bounce Blast? It's a fun little game and at 30 somewhat short levels, it can be a one-sitting type of game as well. The visuals, the music, the gameplay, several modes to choose from... it all works together pretty well to make for an entertaining game that keeps you on your toes. But issues like questionable deaths, unkillable enemies and some potentially iffy powerup frequency choices put a few blemishes on this game's vector graphics-inspired visage. So while it is a game I recommend, it's one that could have used a few tweaks in my opinion.

Score- 7.5 / 10

[table]Disclaimer - Developer submitted me a free key for the game for review purposes.[/table]

Hyper Bounce blast is an interesting take on the Shmup genre. By combining it with elements of platform games and puzzle games, Hyper Bounce Blast is a unique, if unimpressive shooter.

The idea is to shoot the red enemies, and jump on the blue enemies while collecting fragments that the red ships leave behind. Once you've gained a plethora of these fragments, the aim is to "bank" the points by jumping to the top of the screen before the wave ends.

The vector styled graphics suit the game well, and controller support is tight and responsive. It also makes you brain think asymmetrically as you have to figure out which enemies to shoot and when to shoot them, as shooting a blue enemy renders it unable to be jumped on, and jumping on enemies is the only way to make your ship impervious to enemy fire. 

While the ideas around the game are great, keyboard and mouse movement lacks finesse, and it's very easy to lose track of your subtly coloured aiming reticle. The bosses and bullet patterns are also unfortunately very generic, seemingly ripped directly from Cave Shmups.

That being said, the game has a definitely high difficulty curve, and the price is right, so if you fancy a challenge, it's worth taking a look at. It's a good game, but not a great one.

My rating: 6 out of 10.

24282773.review:
[i]Hyper Bounce Blast[/i] is the latest game from Flump Studios, which you may have heard of from their successful titles, such as Horizon Shift.

Always faithful to the genre, [i]Hyper Bounce Blast[/i] is a sweet and delicious homage to the 80-90's Shm'up wave, and it succeeds wonderfully in offering unique gameplay mechanics.

You're controlling a bouncing ship with the ability to wall jump and bounce on the ennemies. 
As long as you're in the air, you're entirely invincible from every form of threat. But if you land on the ground, you'll be vunerable ! As compensation, you will also get to collect the points from the kills you've just made. And if you reach the ceiling, you will bank your chain.

And that is what the game is mostly about. You need to focus either on jumping or shooting, or maybe both if you're awesome like that.

Oh, should I talk about the Hyper ? When your Hyper bar is full, you can release your full power, and give headaches to your ennemies by going BWAAAAAAAAAAAAH for a few seconds. This can save your life, really. And give you hell of a lot of points, secondarily, but make sure to activate it as close as you can from the top of the screen!

As usual, you have access to different game modes, each with their own leaderboards. While I do wish the game the success it deserves, I must admit I love the small community it currently gathers, just for the fact you can have a say with your scores, as modest as they are. It's way more rewarding than ending up in the 100th page of leaderboards, where nobody will ever find you again. 

I found [i]Hyper Bounce Blast[/i] graphically stunning, and it runs smoother than ever. Every new game from the Studios is yet another big step towards indie professionalism (careful not to go too far, or you'll get tired, Paul!), and I'm really excited to see what is next to come out of their magic hat of high-quality games.

Whether you're a retro gamer, shmup-lover, or simply someone who wants to discover that genre, I can only recommend [i]Hyper Bounce Blast[/i] : it is made with passion, doubtlessly.

24067548.review:
[quote][i]Review copy provided from developer. Note that my ability to enjoy a game is not influenced by how I recieved it.[/i][/quote]

[h1]Hyper Bounce Blast[/h1] is a hectic arcade shoot 'em up, with a bit of platforming blended in to add an extra bit of flavour. 

Gameplay-wise, you take on the role of an energetic shooting machine and plough your way through chaotic waves with the ability to not only blast an infinite amount of bullets in your enemies' path, but to bounce your way whilst doing so. But does this platforming mechanic affect the gameplay enough for it to be an effective use of innovation, [i]and warrant a whole word in the title[/i]? Definitely. You'll see why as I go on to explain. Throughout [i]Hyper Bounce Blast[/i] you'll be constantly trying to stay off the floor. Why? Whenever you are touching this floor, you are vulnerable to bullets. However, when you bounce your way through the level (via jumping on to anything that's blue) you are not only invulnerable to these bullets, but also absorbing them, turning your [i]bullet hell[/i] into a [i]bullet heaven[/i]. There are also other features of the bounciness, such as multipliers and the screen-clearing [i]hyper[/i] that annihilates everything with some serious visual displays.

You have a couple of gamemodes to choose from which sounds like it would be a huge portion of the replayability, but unfortunately each mode doesn't seem [i]that[/i] worthy of its own mode and rather changes some minor settings such as number of lives, etc. Then there's the [i][b]Tournament Mode[/b][/i]. The speed of the game is changed to an incredibly fast pace (this can be done yourself in the settings for the all gamemodes, so I don't see why it has been granted its own mode) which ultimately conflicts with your platforming abilities. There is no skillful way to speedily bounce through a level, you will almost always fail or be granted success by pure chance. This being said, the gameplay as a whole is [i]very[/i] entertaining and will provide both an enjoyable and satisfying experience through both classic shoot 'em up action and innovation.

On an aesthetic side of things, Hyper Bounce Blast does provide a vibrant experience, but one that is merely passable. There is nothing special about these graphics and whilst having and overwhelming amount of colourful visuals, they unfortunately show to be slightly underwhelming. This being said, they are by no means 'bad'.

[i]Hyper Bounce Blast[/i] is filled with electronic tunes from the musical mastermind, [i]Quantum Firefly[/i]. I will say that whilst not being outstandingly complex they will soothe a simple mind, thus I enjoyed them. 

USD $5 is a fair enough asking price. Not the cheapest, but I assume on sale it will be very much worth it.

Want to know if you can configure and rebind everything to your hipster needs? Sure. There is an extensive list of settings that you can knock yourself out with.


[h1][b]Summary:[/b][/h1]

[b]Pros:[/b]
✔ Enjoyable, innovative gameplay
✔ Combination of genres works
✔ Slick electronic tunes


[b]Cons:[/b]
✘ Gamemodes aren't that great, especially the [i][b]Tournament Mode[/b][/i]

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
[b]Hyper Bounce Blast[/b] is something new to a seemingly crowded genre of shoot 'em up games. It will provide an enjoyable and unique experience, one that's not to be missed by people wanting something refreshing.

[b]Rating:[/b] 
7.3/10 - ★★★☆☆

23571076.review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] SHMUP fans wanting an alternative experience. [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]
If you're looking for the same old same old from the SHMUP experience, you can look away from Hyper Bounce Blast. Just like Horizon Shift, it makes a small twist in the genre by adding a platforming mechanic, and that mechanic is well implemented in terms of gameplay. There's something satisfying to bouncing from enemy to enemy while shooting everything in site. And this core gameplay feels fresh in the genre, even if it may not have a lot of staying power over the long haul. Look, this is a 5 dollar game, and there are things that could have raised the game to the next level in terms of replayability, such as some random enemy formats or different options. But the core experience keeps thing simple and yet fun, allowing you to focus on small simple bite-sized elements in the game that combine to a good couple hour experience. It's a developer that doesn't want to make the same old game: he's experimental: and not in the “artsy” type of way. It's the gameplay mechanics he plays with: and I will openly admit, I'm always fascinated by those who try something different in a genre that usually keeps things safe. And good on Flump studios for producing games that change things up: and deliver an enjoyable experience.

[b]Video Review: [/b] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jUGUbQabLmI

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*]  The addition of the platforming mechanic adds to the chaos, and it does work. Gives good incentive to use with not only the point multiplier, but the ability to absorb bullets. Complements gameplay, without being distracting.
[*] Boss battles do a good job of testing skill, without being overly complicated. Introduces small new mechanics that don't go too far off what has been played up to that point.
[*] Simple aesthetic compliments the gameplay here. Simple to see action, and even through the chaos, I felt like I could easily see everything at all times.
[*] Bank system is cool. Gives good incentive while not being forced to use it. A good point chasing mechanic.
[*] Color mechanic. Every enemy is easily identifiable in terms of weaknesses because of this color system. Good information that's easily processed by the player.
[*] Controls works for the game on both the controller and keyboard/mouse (I prefer the controller here). 
[*] Music selection once again complements the action here (yes, I have used the word complement a lot in this review, but when a word works, it works.)
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] Some modes don't work, like the Tournament mode. The new platforming mechanic + the speed element makes movement too fast, not letting you capitalize on the gameplay in question. 
[*] A mode that had some randomization of enemy placement would have really taken the replayability of the game to the next level. 
[*] A lot of my complaints really comes down to mechanics regarding the length/variety of the game over time. Again, at the 5 dollar price tag, I shouldn't expect a lot, but I do wonder if the next game in the series can really push the envelope with enemy variety and mechanics, and make a indie hit. I end up wanting more.
[*] Would have liked to see an option to change the color on the aiming reticle. The gray on the black background, while not distracting, doesn't really help. 
[/list]

23475869.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
Hyper Bounce Blast was developed by Flump Studios and published by KISS ltd. It is described as a Shoot Em' Up combined with the classic platformer style which is kind of unique for this style of gameplay. It also seems to be a sort of bullet hell game but without the free flying and sort of wall jumping along.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
This game seems to be a rather different kind of Shoot Em' Up/Bullet hell game with some platforming elements combined into the game, which make it much harder than your average Bullet Hell / Shoot Em' Up. The main mechanic is being able to wall jump from the left and right wall, which means there is also gravity involved in the game. This really separates it from other similar games of this genre, and makes a different sort of gameplay style from other games like this. I rather liked the platforming elements that are implemented into the game, it gives it that more difficult sort of feel when you are trying to avoid the bullets but are trapped in the corner.

Although it seems to be that bit more different from the other sort of games of this genre, it does have a big flaw that I personally don't like. Some of the bosses in the game have a rapid amount of bullets that are being shot at you, and compared to the size of your character makes it so difficult to avoid the bullets. Especially if you wall jump and try to swerve your way through the bullets you are almost certain to get hit. I really don't like this, even though this game is really fun, but just a bit too difficult that takes some of that fun out of the game.

With the game being practically the same over and over again, you would expect there to be several different types of game modes. Some of which are locked and can be unlocked by progressing far enough into other game modes. You have the Arcade Classic, start with 2 lives and try to fight through all the waves, you get a checkpoint before and after each boss battle. Arcade Arrange is the same as Arcade Classic except you have no extra lives but you get a checkpoint after each level. Time rush, see how far you can get with in a fully powered up ship when the game speeds up each wave. Lastly there is Tournament Mode, see how far you can get in a fully powered up ship with each wave increased speed.

There is a nice range of different game modes to keep you entertained for longer than you normally would. There are also 2 locked gamemodes which I don't know what they are as I haven't progressed enough to unlock them. I for one don't personally like the locked gamemodes for the game, forces you to get far into the game to unlock other modes which you may or may not like. There is online leaderboards, if you are the more competitive sort of players and want to try to beat other people at their score, I for one am not very competitive so it doesn't compel me to play more and try to beat other peoples score.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
+ Has some platforming elements, makes it unique from other games of the similar genre
+ Lots of Game Modes
+ Online Leaderboards
+ Full Controller Support
+ Steam Trading Cards & Achievements

[h1]Cons[/h1]
- Lots of bullet, makes the game too hard and takes some fun from the game
- 2 Locked gamemodes, unsure why they are locked

[h1]Result / Final Thoughts[/h1]
Hyper Bounce Blast is a unique Shoot Em' Up / Bullet Hell game that has some platforming elements to it, the game itself is fairly difficult a bit too difficult that it takes the fun out of it at times. There is plenty of game modes to play through, although two of them are locked. There is a competitive leaderboard, full controller support, steam trading cards and Achievements. Would recommend to those of you who love Bullet Hell games.

[b]Rating: 6.8/10[/b]

This game is a very creative take on a shmup with platforming elements. Shoot the reds, bounce on the blues. Kill all of the few green enemies in each wave to reach a very fun bonus round. Gameplay is simple and easy to start, but difficult to master with so much going on! I was immediately reminded of Geometry Wars not only by the visual style but also by the mess of things happening all at once. Fortunately, in this game you are completely invulnerable to enemy attacks as long as you stay airborne by bouncing off the blue enemies. As an added bonus, when bouncing, you actually absorb enemy fire to power up your screen-obliterating special attack! Despite the invulnerability, it can still be quite challenging as blue enemies aren't always spaced out evenly. If you aren't keeping the reds and their projectiles thinned out, hitting the ground can spell the instant loss of a life. Boss battles limit your bouncing and provide a bit more of a bullet hell experience, but are not too challenging and very fair once you learn their patterns.

All in all, Hyper Bounce Blast is a lot of fun and can be very addicting. I definitely recommend it!
